intro: Rumex pulcher var. hirtus, commonly known as the hairy dock, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Polygonaceae family, characterized by its distinctive leaf structures and flowering habits. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–100 cm, with heart-shaped, hairy leaves that are often reddish in color. Its flowers are small and greenish-white, arranged in dense, upright clusters known as scorpioid cymes. It thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides, riverbanks, and in open woodlands.
